The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.

subdebateinfo.title: Agreement for Members to Contribute Remotely to Parliamentary Proceedings

p.span: Agreement for Members to Contribute Remotely to Parliamentary Proceedings
Presentation
Mr EVANS (Brisbane—Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management) (10:01): I present a document called Agreement for Members to Contribute Remotely to Parliamentary Proceedings.

This agreement is made pursuant to the Resolution adopted by the House of Representatives on 23 March 2020, entitled Special provisions for human biosecurity emergency period, for the upcoming sittings of the House of Representatives from Monday, 22 November 2021 to Thursday, 2 December 2021.
(1) Members not physically present in Parliament House may participate in proceedings of the House of Representatives Chamber or the Federation Chamber, as provided by this agreement, if:
(a) they participate via the official parliamentary video facility only; and
(b) the Speaker is satisfied the Member is unable to physically attend Parliament due to reasons related to the COVID-19 pandemic;

(2) Reasons to be provided to allow the Speaker to make a decision in accordance with 1(b) above should be provided by the Leader of the House to the Speaker for a Government Member, the Manager of Opposition Business to the Speaker for an Opposition Member and directly to the Speaker for a non-aligned Member. The reasons should address the personal circumstances related to the COVID-19 pandemic that have made it essentially impossible, unreasonably impracticable, or would give rise to an unreasonable risk for the Member to physically attend Parliament;
(3) The standing orders apply except as affected by this agreement;
(4) Members participating in proceedings by this agreement must use the official parliamentary video facility and be present at either an Electorate Office or a Commonwealth Parliament Office;
(5) Members present by the official parliamentary video facility may speak only after being recognised by the Chair:
(a) for the purposes of making a speech; or
(b) to ask or answer a question at Question Time;
(6) Members present by the official parliamentary video facility may not:
(a) vote or be counted for quorum;
(b) move or second any motion;
(c) move or second any amendment to a motion or bill;
(d) propose or support a proposal to discuss a matter of public importance;
(e) call for a division; or
(f) call for a quorum to be counted;
(7) Notice is to be provided to the Chair, 15 minutes prior to:
(a) a Member, participating in proceedings by the official parliamentary video facility, seeking to make a speech;
(b) a Member, participating in proceedings by the official parliamentary video facility, seeking to ask a question in Question Time; and

(c) Question Time, by the Leader of the House, indicating whether any Minister will be present during Question Time by the official parliamentary video facility and is therefore available to answer questions;

(8) At the conclusion of a question made through the official parliamentary video facility, the questioner participating in accordance with paragraph 7(b) above shall remain available to seek the call if that member wishes to raise a point of order during the answer; and
(9) Contributions to proceedings made by Members present by the official parliamentary video facility will be recorded in Hansard.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 33rd report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 115 petitions and 14 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.

Of the petitions I present today, two petitions have collected so many signatures that they are in the top 10 of the largest e-petitions the committee has ever received. Another, scheduled to be presented by a different member this fortnight, is the fifth largest e-petition ever received. These three petitions alone together collected over 417,000 unique signatures in the four weeks that they were open.

This is a significant amount of public interaction with the petitioning process in a relatively short amount of time. It is evidence that petitioning the parliament, and participating in democracy, is something that Australians are actively interested in and will continue with vigour.

The committee are pleased to be able to support this high level of public petitioning and continue to consider how the process, the e-petitioning system and the petitioning information displayed on our website can be improved. A project to further improve user experience with the e-petitioning system is due to commence shortly, and I will continue to provide updates to the House on its progress.

Mr Speaker, I would also like to acknowledge this being your last day as Speaker and thank you for your continued support of the work of the committee and the democratic act of petitioning. I wish you all the best as you transition to your new/old role, and I look forward to providing updates to your incoming successor. Thank you very much.
The SPEAKER: Thank you.
PETITIONS
Presentation
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following petitions:
COVID-19

So private sector workers and small business owners that are ordered into lockdown are paid their normal income, just as the bureaucrats and politicians are. No one forced into lockdown should be financially worse off
We therefore ask the House to enact legislation to ensure that no worker or small business owner is financially disadvantaged by lockdown orders
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN3230)
COVID-19: Vaccination
The Covid Vaccines are in their relative medical infancy as compared to long standing vaccines for more well established diseases.
Many Australians have legitimate concern as to the efficacy and particularly any harmful side effects of the Covid Vaccines.
We say that every Australian has the right to choose in regards to Covid vaccination.
Government has begun the implementation of measures offering favouritism to vaccinated persons, and limiting the everyday freedoms of those who are not currently vaccinated.
We say this is discriminatory and should cease immediately.
We therefore ask the House to consider legislation that would prevent a person being discriminated against, or in any way treated differently on the basis of their Covid Vaccination status.
from 13,358 citizens (Petition No. EN3233)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Investigate and amend vaccine procedure to medical staff and to aspirate (Pull back plunger) prior to injection. A potential to prevent thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) Blood Clots.

Hence, safe intramuscular injection, with aspiration prior to injection (attempt to draw blood in to needle to avoid incorrect vascular injection), could be a potential preventive measure when administering Covid-19 vaccines and avoid Blood Clots.

We therefore ask the House to advise Medical staff to amend vaccine procedure to aspirate (Pull back plunger) prior to injection and prevent accidental vascular injection as an attempt to reduce thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS) Blood Clots
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN3234)
Members of Parliament

Members of parliament regularly make decisions that affect millions of Australian Residents. We should have full confidence that the MP's voting on bills put before parliament be free from the effects of drugs and alcohol.
Random Drug testing is common in some industries already and should be in place for all MP's
There are different types of drug test that look for traces of drugs in saliva, blood, urine, breath, sweat and hair
MP's should also have drug and alcohol test published online and freely available for all constituents to be able to have access to view the results.

MP's should also be suspended without pay until the return a negative test within 2 week if they return a positive test during random testing period. Testing positive should result in consequences for all MP's as they are representatives of the communities they server.
We therefore ask the House to consider the mandatory Drug and Alcohol testing for all MP's to uphold the parliamentary integrity of its members and the people they serve.
from 194 citizens (Petition No. EN3238)
COVID-19: Vaccination
The introduction of Mandatory Vaccination and the Vaccine Passport in Australia will create an underclass of citizens who will be denied basic human rights.
The adoption and acceptance of the Rapid Antigen Test will enable the vaccine-hesitant to work, travel and live normal lives.
Prime Minister Morrison's government has the power to adopt and implement the use of these tests across Australia.

We therefore ask the House to enact a Bill to adopt and implement the use of Rapid Antigen Tests across Australia to enable citizens to prove their COVID status to facilitate participation in all aspects of society.
from 6,307 citizens (Petition No. EN3239)
Diabetes

The Omnipod DASH insulin pump launched in Australia however many Australians living with Type 1 Diabetes, are unable to access this new technology because it is not covered by private health insurance nor subsidised on the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).
WHAT IS IT?
The Omnipod DASH Insulin Management System is a tubeless insulin pump system consisting of:
• A tubeless, wearable, waterproof* Pod delivering insulin non-stop for up to 72 hours and
• Touch screen and Bluetooth enabled Personal Diabetes Manager (PDM) controlling the Pod that is used to program basal and bolus insulin.
THE CURRENT SITUATION?

To date, attempts to reimburse the Omnipod DASH System have been unsuccessful. After 9 months of deliberation by the Department of Health, the Department advises that the Omnipod DASH System does not fit comfortably within the current subsidisation model for traditional insulin pump products and that a re-submission seeking subsidisation of the Omnipod DASH System, under the NDSS through the Health Technology Assessment pathway, is required. This process will take a further 8-12 months to reach the committee meeting, with no guarantee of reimbursement at the end of this process. As the Omnipod DASH System received favourable clinical expert advice into the Prostheses List Advisory Committee, it is understood that this further review is around process, not cost-effectiveness.

We therefore ask the House to seek ministerial intervention by Minister Greg Hunt to bypass this long and costly process and have the Omnipod DASH insulin pump added to the National Diabetes Services Scheme as a matter of urgency.
from 4,712 citizens (Petition No. EN3240)
Australian Society
"John Howard was one of the most strident opponents of an identity card, warning that it would be a "draconian intrusion" into the lives of Australians."

In the mid 1980s, the Hawke Labor Government was arguing that a national identification card was needed to crack down on tax avoidance, but opponents of the Australia Card generated mass opposition with a national advertising campaign...

BOB HAWKE: … The Australia Card legislation, which my Government sees as essential to our continued campaign both to finally eliminate tax evasion and fraud in this country and also to the elimination of welfare cheating.
Bob Hawke fought for the Australia Card all the way to an election in 1987. At the time, during a long stint in Opposition, the current Prime Minister John Howard was a strong opponent.

"JOHN HOWARD: When you realise that the assumption of the Australia Card legislation is that every Australian is a cheat, when you realise that it involves establishing a level of intrusion of a draconian kind into the day to day activities of many people and when people really read and understand the legislation..."
We therefore ask the House to support Former Liberal Prime minister John Howard's position and place a permanent ban on the cards in any form

Australia is a party to seven core international human rights treaties. The right to freedom of movement is contained in articles 12 and 13 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR)
from 9,627 citizens (Petition No. EN3241)
Housing Affordability
To the House of Representatives.
There is a disparity in what was once called the "Australian dream", owning one's own home.

Presently our Government sells our land, our country, to the highest overseas bidder regardless of whether they are Australian citizens or not. It neglects our own citizens, those who have worked hard to make Australia what it is, those who have paid their taxes to this country.
Our government has created an oligopoly of land ownership with no limits to how much land one person can own, regardless of the fact that our land is finite.
Through debt and fear, these are the tools our government uses to govern the population.
The situation has gradually worsened becoming more difficult with each decade that passes.
Gone are the days where you could easily earn 16% interest from a bank saving account.
To make things worse, the national government's incentive scheme, the "First Home Saver Account", inflated house prices like never before.
Is this sustainable? Is this empathetic governing? or is this a case of housing inflation gone mad?
So how can we fix this horrible destructive disparity?
We therefore ask the House to
1) Limit land ownership.
2) Remove the tax benefits and negative gearing.
3) Make citizenship a requirement.
4) Release more land.
5) Tighten regulations regarding the real estate industry and increase penalties for breaching regulations.
If you are one of the many Australians who feels neglected by the government.
Then sign this petition to show your disapproval before the situation worsens.
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN3249)
Law Enforcement

The Identify and Disrupt Bill 2021 grants the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) the power to modify, add, copy, or delete data, on a person's online accounts.

So what this means is that the AFP can log into your Email, your Facebook, Instagram any other social media, and not only view it but actually alter it however they want. They can send emails on your behalf, they can post things on your behalf, they can engage in criminal activity on your behalf in order to reach their objective. And if they want to throw you under the bus, you're just collateral damage.
This will not only turn Australia into a bigger surveillance state, but it will make the government the enemy of Australians.
The Identify and Disrupt Bill 2021 needs to be repealed. It violates Australian civil rights and basic human liberties. The online space will no longer be safe for Australians.
Do you really want to live in a country where the government controls every online account you have?
We therefore ask the House to Repeal the Identify and Disrupt Bill 2021
from 282 citizens (Petition No. EN3250)

subdebateinfo.title: Compensation for Detriment Caused by Defective Administration Scheme

p.span: Compensation for Detriment Caused by Defective Administration Scheme

Claims made under the Commonwealths Scheme for Compensation for Detriment caused by Defective Administration (CDDA Scheme), are decided by the same entity that is accused of causing the detriment, in effect they are the judge, jury and executioner...
The undersigned state that this is an unacceptable process, more so in light of the avenue for appeals Commonwealth Ombudsman that only has the power to make a recommendation...

The undersigned state this process need to be moved to an enactment, where the decision maker needs be required to give a reason for decision, in doing so this will allow any aggrieved person to engage review by the Federal Court or the Federal Circuit Court, and or appeal to the Administrative Appeal Tribunal.
We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes as to cause CDDA decisions to be made under an enactment.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN3251)
Law Enforcement

The Identify and Disrupt Bill 2021 grants the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) the power to modify, add, copy, or delete data, on a person's online accounts.

This means is that the AFP can log into your Email, your Facebook, Instagram any other social media, and not only view it but actually alter it however they want. They can send emails on your behalf, they can post things on your behalf, they can engage in criminal activity on your behalf in order to reach their objective.
This bill will passed both houses on the 25th of August. We, the people, stand to protect our fundamental right to privacy.
We therefore ask the House to reject the Identify and Disrupt Bill 2021.
from 326 citizens (Petition No. EN3253)
COVID-19: Vaccination

The petition is to oppose another petition which requests importing Chinese COVID-19 vaccines. The Chinese vaccines do not have a good efficacy compared to the current vaccines in Australia, and get many criticises around the world. Some countries importing Chinese vaccines are still suffering a great lose, e.g. even the UAE (10m population) gots 50% full covered by Sinophram vaccines long time ago (now 75% with booster shoots), and the country is still having around 1 thousand new COVID-19 cases everyday. It is a waste of money to import Chinese COVID-19 vaccines.
We therefore ask the House to prevent any attempt to import Chinese COVID-19 vaccines like CoronaVac and Sinopharm.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN3260)
COVID-19: International Travel

Hundreds of thousands of international students in Australia are unable to bring their spouse and/or children to Australia and reunite with their family. Some of them have not seen their children for more than 2 years now due to the travel ban and strict exemption criteria that only allow entry in extreme circumstances such as death or critical illness of a close family member. They are some of the few students left in Australia since the COVID-19 pandemic started. They do not want to return home and lose the investment they have made in their studies, work and future in Australia. However, some of them are leaving because family is more important.

Australian states have approved some action plans to bring back international students, but none mention the children or immediate family members of international students already in Australia. That's unfair and inhumane. The government is only nice to those who can bring more money.

As a signatory to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, Australia must prioritize cases involving children to keep families together. No child should suffer regardless of their immigration status.

We therefore ask the House to end family separation and show compassion during these most difficult times by granting the immediate family members of student visa holders a travel exemption on compassionate grounds.
from 314 citizens (Petition No. EN3262)
Electoral Communications
This petition draws attention to the inundation of Australians with unsolicited political digital communications by certain political parties, with no way to prevent them.
The problem:
1) The Spam Act prohibits unsolicited digital messages, but the ACMA specifically exempts political organisations;
2) Even with this exemption, the act states: "Commercial electronic messages must contain a functional unsubscribe facility (Ref-2/18)";
3) Unlike postal mailouts, digital messages can be cheaply sent to everyone, without the need to appropriately target communications;
4) Some political parties are actively abusing this exemption with impunity.
We therefore ask the House to
1) Introduce legislation compelling political parties to abide by minimum conditions for unsolicited digital messages:
a) Register all SMS numbers and accounts from which unsolicited political messages are sent with the AEC, which then publishes these on the web;
b) Require 30 days notice to the AEC of any change to the above addresses;
c) Clarify that political parties are NOT exempt from the requirement from providing an unsubscribe mechanism;
d) Define penalties that reflect the high standard political organisations must be held to;
2) Recognise this enables citizens to self-regulate communications and prevent the evasive techniques common to spam messages;
3) Recognise this balances the needs of the democratic process against the rights of citizens to be free from harassment;
4) Recognise failure to act on this risks a snowballing effect, compelling other parties to engage in similar tactics and normalising the behaviour the Spam Act seeks to prevent.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN3264)
COVID-19

To decrease suicide rates, mental illnesses and alcohol abuse in Australia, to boost the economy in both Australia and nationwide. To save $ on in effective covid 19 principalities such as PCR tests, daily press conferences, mask mandates & to free the freedom fighters. To connect families back together again. To prepare the Lords children for his return.

We therefore ask the House to liaise with other countries of interest to form an alliance and open up the borders for ALL. Vaccination passport exempt and vice versa. The great Lord gave all of us an immune system to fight viruses and our personal health is our choice. Corporations, nations & individuals worldwide are severely suffering both mentally and economically from both lockdowns and border closures and for this we ask that the Australian Government put an end to these Covid 19 principalities. PCR testing has been scientifically proven to be in accurate and expensive and for these reasons we ask that the practice of this also end. Signing in goes against our right to privacy and since masks do not provide protection against the virus we ask that the mask mandate also be removed as it's proving to cause mental illnesses and anxiety. We ask that you also free the " freedom fighters " for they do not know the words & teachings of the holy bible but they do know good from evil & they do know the Lord to be both their saviour & their King.
from 5,686 citizens (Petition No. EN3266)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
CALLING ON THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES TO TERMINATE THE COVID19 BIO SECURITY EMERGENCY
We call upon the House to terminate Australia's human biosecurity COVID19 emergency.
Emergency power is found in The Biosecurity ACT 2015, Section 475 which states;
(1) The Governor General may declare that a human biosecurity emergency exists if the Health Minister is satisfied that:
(a) a listed human disease is posing a severe and immediate threat, or is causing harm, to human health on a nationally significant scale.

Australia's emergency is based upon data from the Polymerase Chain Reaction test (PCR) whose inventor Kary Mullis regarded 'inappropriate to detect a viral infection'. (Torsten Engelbrecht and Konstantin Demeter, June 20, 2020. 'Covid19 PCR Tests are Scientifically Meaningless.')
Although 'inappropriate' the PCR test is the sole basis for case numbers, lockdowns, social distancing, social and economic crisis, fear, and experimental vaccines.

Australian deaths remain relatively stable, as per winter flu season. (ABS 'Provisional deaths data for measuring changes in patterns of mortality during the COVID-19 pandemic and recovery period'). ABS number covid deaths at 1012 at 1/9/2021 with most aged 70 to 90 years.
The House has failed in its duty of care to provide early treatments to those with covid. (Peter McCullough MD, American Frontline Doctors and Doctors for Covid Ethics).
The House has failed by pushing 'experimental vaccines' without short- or long-term safety research.
This petition renders authorisation of The Biosecurity ACT 2015 Section 475 (1) (a) unlawful.
We therefore ask the House to immediately terminate the COVID19 Bio-security response.
from 6,763 citizens (Petition No. EN3277)
Hindus

Recent events in Parliament and the Australian media of prejudice and bias against Hindus, pose grave risks to Hindus and all those who may be perceived as Hindus in our community. This is particularly terminology, used with impunity by Greens politicians, by activists, as well as in social media and other media, such as Hindu Supremacists, Hindu Extremists and Hindutva Extremists.

These terms target Hindus and Hinduism, they foster hatred toward Hindus, anti-immigrant sentiment, anti-Asian sentiment and encourage the general public to mischaracterise Hindus as terrorists. This damages social cohesion increases violence and has no correlation to any known risks to Australia, other countries, nor for that matter has Hindutva, which includes many aspects of ordinary Hindu cultural expression that could be captured under the stereotypes of extremism, ever been conclusively proven to comprise extremist ideology.

We therefore ask the House to impose a ban on the use of any terminology that includes the terms Hindu, Hindutva or Hinduism in relation to radicalisation, religious extremism or Supremacism in the same way as it is incorrect to use terms like Islam and Muslim, or other terms prescribing religious cultural and ethnic identities in Australia as names for terror ideology.

Similarly we request the terminology of Hinduphobia, as per the Oxford English Dictionary be recognised as a legitimate form of bias and prejudice within Australian society and include this term within any official, governance and institutional literature alongside correlated terms.
from 4,379 citizens (Petition No. EN3280)
Dental Health

Dental health has scientifically been proven a key pillar in upholding the health of a person, with the issue of wisdom teeth threatening this greatly; they can cause cysts, degradation of the mouth, infection, and other serious injury. However, many Australians are unable to access affordable wisdom tooth extraction (often costing thousands). This is a violation of a person's right to health and happiness, segregated by class and wealth. It is the belief of the Australian people that we should take this small step closer to true equality for all in Australia, by providing medical aid where it's needed most.
We therefore ask the House to reform Medicare to cover all forms of wisdom tooth extraction, ensuring that anyone of any age can access treatment without fear of debt.
from 123 citizens (Petition No. EN3282)
Taiwan

The world treats the Republic of China (Taiwan) as a country in all means except for name. Taiwan has its own democratically elected government, military, currency, legal system and world class public health system. Taiwanese citizens travel freely on Taiwan Government issued passports which are widely accepted by almost every country in the world, including Australia.

Yet, when it comes to formal recognition, Taiwan is blocked from global institutions and multilateral trade agreements due to countries desire to trade with (and bullying from) the Peoples Republic of China (PRC). The time has come for the world to rectify this situation and Australia can lead the world to do what is right. There is one China and one Taiwan.
We should be brave enough to stand up to China and recognize the Taiwanese government as the legitimate government of Taiwan, just as we recognize the PRC as the legitimate government of China.
By recognizing the Taiwanese government we can encourage both China and Taiwan to negotiate their own terms for mutual recognition of each other as sovereign nations and reduce the risk of war.
We therefore ask the House to recognize the Republic of China (Taiwan) as a sovereign state and regard the government in Taiwan as having the status of the national government of the ROC (Taiwan).
from 3,069 citizens (Petition No. EN3283)
Biosecurity

We are opposed to the Biosecurity Amendment (Enhanced Risk Management) Bill 2021, specifically in relation to broadening the scope of the current Biosecurity Act 2015 to include biosecurity enforcement orders upon "classes of individuals", specifically requiring them to wear specified clothing or equipment (108M), to be relocated and detained (108L), for an indefinite time (108 (2) ) and to provide body samples to the World Health Organization (108P).

While we understand that these changes are meant to be imposed upon groups arriving into the country by plane or vessels, it does not expressly exclude the possibility of it also being applied to other "classes" of people such as the unvaccinated, or to certain ethnic, religious or politicosocial groups residing within Australia.

We therefore ask the House to reject this bill. In its present form it does not offer adequate protections or limitations of overreaching use against certain classes of people, such as the unvaccinated.
from 163,744 citizens (Petition No. EN3285)
Gambling

It's scientifically known that some people are more susceptible to gambling addiction than others. Our children are being subjected to gambling adverts very regularly via apps and social media and also national television - it is everywhere on a scale that was not the case 30 years ago.
We therefore ask the House to further restrict the capabilities for gambling companies to advertise their services online, on national television, billboards and radio etc.
from 92 citizens (Petition No. EN3287)
Electoral Communications

With the recent misuse of this exemption by a certain political party, it's time that citizens of Australia choose whether or not to receive political messages from individual parties. Only messages of critical national importance should received without consent.
We therefore ask the House to remove political party exemption from the Spam Act 2003, and ensure that private citizens are only interrupted by messages of critical national importance.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN3288)
Law Enforcement

The parliament of Australia has passed intrusive, draconian new surveillance legislation under the usual post-9/11 guise of national security, known as the Surveillance Legislation Amendment (Identify and Disrupt) Bill 2021. The new laws simply go too far.

The law allows for law enforcement agencies to control, manipulate, place, or remove data or information from devices, and monitor network activity under specific warrants. However, the most concerning addition to their arsenal is their ability to take over and control people's online accounts, including but not limited to social media profiles.

The new tools created by the law, such as data disruption warrants, are too wide in scope, and are too easy for law enforcement entities to obtain. They go well beyond what most Australians would consider reasonable for law enforcement, as demonstrated by the immense public backlash to the legislation.

Australians deserve digital privacy online and on their own devices. This is already extremely difficult to achieve with the presence of immense private and public data harvesting campaigns, and is now almost completely eradicated thanks to the Identify and Disrupt legislation.

We therefore ask the House to repeal the legislation entirely, replacing it with a declaration of a right to digital privacy for all Australians, to prevent our further slide into a surveillance state, an event that has been in a slow progression for decades.
from 253 citizens (Petition No. EN3289)
COVID-19

The Doherty Institute report is based on faulty assumptions (such as an assumption that the Delta variant is no worse than Alpha variant) and shows unacceptable outcomes (such as more than 5000 deaths over the course of an outbreak, even with over 80% average vaccination rates).
We therefore ask the House to reject the Doherty Institute's report and seek a new report with:
*Valid assumptions based on observed data
*Modelling which covers the entire outbreak rather than just the first 180 days
*Modelling which covers children's inability to get vaccinated
*Modelling which covers uneven vaccination distribution (particularly for remote Aboriginal communities)
*Modelling which compares an outbreak starting from a single infected individual to that which would occur if restrictions were lifted with our current 25,000+ known infections
*Modelling which would not overwhelm the hospital systems
*Modelling which does not forecast over 5000 deaths from a single outbreak
from 4,038 citizens (Petition No. EN3292)
HomeBuilder Grant

When the Federal Government announced the Home Builder Grant (HBG), it was stated that anyone that signed a building contract between 04/06/2020 and 31/12/2020 and met the set requirements, would receive the grant. This was irrespective of completing the online application. This was further reiterated by Minister Sukkar in various interviews. The Minister also assured that applications were just a formality. The deadline was not mentioned in any media releases nor included in the requirements. Due to the high demand for construction and renovations, local councils were overwhelmed and resulted in long delays in building approvals. Also, a shortage of building supplies and Covid-19 restrictions has seen construction time frames extended significantly. Added to this a flawed HBG website and confusing information saw many hard-working Australians unable to apply for this grant even though, according to the Minister for Housing, they are eligible. Recently, the HBG portal has reopened for people who started their applications. However, this was not the case for people who met the requirements but did not start the application. This is because they were unaware of the closing date, caused by a lack of clarity. Missing out on the grant has severely affected my physical and mental health mental.
We therefore ask the House to reopen the application and comply with promises made by the Government and Minister for Housing and Homelessness per the National Partnerships Agreement.
from 128 citizens (Petition No. EN3293)
HomeBuilder Grant

When the Federal Government announced the Home Builder Grant (HBG), they stated that whoever signed a building contract between 04/06/2020 and 31/12/2020 and met the set requirements, would receive the grant. This was irrespective of completing the online application. The Minister also assured that applications were just a formality. The deadline was not mentioned in media releases nor included in the requirements. Due to the high demand for construction and renovations, local councils were overwhelmed and resulted in long delays in building approvals. Also a shortage of building supplies and Covid-19 restrictions has seen construction time frames extended significantly. Added to this a flawed HBG website and confusing information saw many hard-working Australians unable to apply for this grant even though, according to the Minister for Housing, they are eligible. Recently, the HBG portal has reopened for people who started their application. However, this was not the case for people who met the requirements but did not start the application due to not being aware of the closing date, caused by misinformation and confusion.. Missing out on the grant has affected the financial stability, mental health and relationships within families of eligible recipients. This has caused a great financial burden to many, some not even sure they can go ahead with their build/renovations..

We therefore ask the House to use its power, as per the National Partnerships Agreement, to extend the application deadline for the HBG to comply with promises made by the Government and Minister for Housing and Homelessness.
from 144 citizens (Petition No. EN3294)
HomeBuilder Grant

When the Federal Government announced the Home Builder Grant (HBG), they stated that whoever signed a building contract between 04/06/2020 and 31/12/2020 and met the set requirements, would receive the grant. This was irrespective of completing the online application. The Minister also assured that applications were just a formality. The deadline was not mentioned in media releases nor included in the requirements. Due to the high demand for construction and renovations, local councils were overwhelmed and resulted in long delays in building approvals. Also a shortage of building supplies and Covid-19 restrictions has seen construction time frames extended significantly. Added to this a flawed HBG website and confusing information saw many hard-working Australians unable to apply for this grant even though, according to the Minister for Housing, they are eligible. Recently, the HBG portal has reopened for people who started their application. However, this was not the case for people who met the requirements but did not start the application. This is because they were unaware of the closing date, caused by confusion or other misinformation. Missing out on the grant has affected the financial stability, mental health and relationships within families of eligible recipients.
With COVID-19 families are already feeling the financial burden of losing their jobs with lockdowns and now are losing $25,000 has caused a huge financial burden.
We therefore ask the House to re-open the home builders portal for all those eligible who meet the criteria who signed contracts on or before 31st March 2021.
from 132 citizens (Petition No. EN3295)
Electoral Communications

The United Australia Party, authorised by Craig Kelly MP have been repeatedly sending SPAM text messages to thousands of constituents without consent. This would normally be federal offence "using a carriage service to menace, harass or cause offence" but it appears the UAP and Craig Kelly MP have immunity.

We therefore ask the House to make it an offence for a political party or a politician to "using a carriage service to menace, harass or cause offence" and that it be a requirement to sign up for such SPAM.
from 24 citizens (Petition No. EN3296)
Members of Parliament

from 233 citizens (Petition No. EN3298)
COVID-19: Vaccination

We are writing to you as a matter of urgency to express our view in relation to the current availability of vaccines for Covid 19. We are a group of extremely concerned citizens and health practitioners who have considered the current vaccines and researched them extensively. Novavax does not appear to have any severe side-effects other than those similar to the flu vaccination. It is a vaccine that is based on older technology which has been around for decades and is a protein-based vaccine not MRNA nor a viral vector vaccine. Novavax has shown exceptional results in the phase 3 clinical trials and phase 1 and 2 prior to this, unlike the current options of Pfizer and AZ vaccines which have not completed Phase 3 clinical trials.

We therefore ask the House to grant this petition in the hopes that you may be able to assist us in a push to fast track the supply of the vaccine Novavax which we are aware is currently being assessed by the TGA. Novavax has shown exceptional results in the phase 3 clinical trials and phase 1 and 2 prior to this, unlike the current options of Pfizer and AZ vaccines which have not completed Phase 3 clinical trials. We feel Australians deserve to have a choice of which vaccine we put into our bodies.

from 13,973 citizens (Petition No. EN3313)
Alzheimer's Disease

Alzheimer's Disease is a progressive disease that results in the deterioration of brain cells and brain connections, causing the loss of certain functions of the brain and body. It leads to the loss of bodily functions, independence and, eventually, death in older Australians. It is currently the second leading cause of death in Australian men and the leading cause of death in Australian women. Though it is one of the leading causes of death in the country, not a lot is known about its causes due to lack of limited investment in research, hindering efforts in prevention and treatment of the disease.

We therefore ask the House to provide and allocate further funding and resources into the research of Alzheimer's disease, its causes and possible treatment and prevention methods to ensure that both quality and quantity of life is improved for those diagnosed with Alzheimer's and their loved ones.

from 665 citizens (Petition No. EN3357)
COVID-19: Vaccination
The government is currently allowing children as young as 12 to provide their own consent for COVID vaccination.

Common law in Australia around medical consent for minors recognises that the authority of a parent decreases as their child becomes increasingly competent. The parental right to determine their child's treatment terminates once a child under the age of 16 is capable of fully understanding the medical treatment proposed.

Whether a particular child has the requisite intelligence and understanding to give a valid consent is a question of fact ie different individuals will have conflicting opinions on this. One individual may deem a 12 year old child capable of understanding the nature, consequences and risks involved in having the COVID vaccine. Another individual may deem the same child incapable of understanding the nature, consequences and risks involved in having the COVID vaccine.

To my knowledge, vaccine providers are not required to use a standardised assessment tool to determine a child's level of understanding prior to vaccine administration. Currently the decision to treat or not treat is in the hands of vaccine providers who could be medical practitioners, registered nurses, enrolled nurses, pharmacists, paramedics or dentists with relevant training in vaccine administration. These practitioners have not necessarily received training in determining whether a child is mature enough to provide consent for medical treatment.
We therefore ask the House to increase the age of consent to 16 for COVID vaccinations.
from 628 citizens (Petition No. EN3359)
Financial Services Industry

The original objective of the Parliamentary Enquiry into the Financial Services industry was to ensure that Consumers had access to professional and cost effective Financial Advice. Unfortunately this has not happened, the cost of Advice now precludes around 80% of eligible consumers. Over the past 12 years the numerous changes to the Advice COMPLIANCE regime through the ALP/FOFA [2009 - 2014] and COALITION FASEA/LIF [2014 - PRESENT] phases has produced many unintended poor consequences for Consumers and the industry in general. Contributions from ASIC, TREASURY and Commissioner Hayne over the years has produced many costly duplications that Consumers are ultimately paying for. It should be noted that Advisers have no choice but to pass the Compliance costs back to their clients. This process is the major contributing factor to the escalation of advice costs where it has risen from $1000 in 2008/9 to $6,000 today for a Consumer to get advice. The latest CONSENT FORMS [part of Hayne RC no 2] and DDO [Direct Distribution Obligation] Legislation have been introduced during the worst of COVID where implementation confusion is widespread amongst Product Providers, Regulators, Advisers and expensive for Consumers. This has been well documented in recent times.

We therefore ask the House to delay the implementation of the DDO and CONSENT FORMS Legislation until 1/7/2022 and after the next Election appoint an independent committee to reform the COMPLIANCE regime to reduce costs and eliminate duplication for Consumers and the Industry in general.
from 2,258 citizens (Petition No. EN3360)
Veterans

Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) s196B details the Functions of Repatriation Medial Authority (RMA), the main function of which is to determine Statements of Principles (SoP) for the purposes of the VEA and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004...
Each SoP lists the factors, at least one of which "must exist before it can be said that, (an injury or disease) is connected with the circumstances of a person's relevant service"...
Almost all, if not all SoP's list a factor of, "inability to obtain appropriate clinical management …"...
This phrasing is such, that a reasonable person would understand this to mean that the onus to "obtain appropriate clinical management" is placed on the Veteran...

From time to time there will be a circumstance whereby the Department of Defence is aware the Veteran has an injury or disease, and the Veteran is not provided appropriate clinical management. And in this circumstance the undersigned believe a factor to reflect this needs to be incorporated into all appropriate SoP's...

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause such change in the legislation, to require that where there is a "factor" for, "inability to obtain appropriate clinical management …", there also be a factor to the effect of, "failure to be provided appropriate clinical management (for said injury or disease).
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN3361)
Veterans

When an application for review of a decision of the Repatriation Commission is made in accordance with Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) s136, VEA s137(1) obliges the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to prepare a report referring to the evidence that is relevant to the review (evidence report), and to cause this evidence report to be served on the Applicant…
*To assist the VRB and provide context, it is a longstanding practice of the Secretary to customarily include "other material" in this evidence report…
It is worth noting that VEA s138(2)(b) provides for the Commission, "to make available such, other material" as it considers may be of assistance to the Board in the exercise of its powers"…

Not only does this seem to be a failure of Natural Justice and questionable Jurisdiction, it also seems that procedures that are or were required by law to be observed in connection with the making of the decision have, or are not being observed.

(*The above information has been obtained from an email drafted by the Executive Officer to Deputy Commissioner NSW/ACT, Client Benefits Division, Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) on 14 July 2020, in relation to FOI 36247)

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes as to ensure the Secretary revert to strictly conforming with VEA s137(1)(a), and cease the longstanding practice of including "other material" or "other information" in evidence reports, and in doing so return natural justice to the decision review processes.
from 78 citizens (Petition No. EN3362)
COVID-19

On 11th September 2021 the Australian Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) took the unprecedented step of effectively banning the prescribing of ivermectin for the treatment of COVID-19 infection in Australia.

Contrary to ill-informed media reporting, ivermectin is an important drug which has been used clinically worldwide for several decades, it is on the WHO list of Essential Drugs and has a wide margin of safety compared to most other drugs (including over the counter medications). This petition objects in the strongest possible terms to the banning of ivermectin prescribing for COVID-19 for the following reasons:

(1) The banning of ivermectin prescribing ignores the wealth of published clinical trial safety and efficacy evidence in the medical literature supporting the use of ivermectin for the management of COVID-19;

(2) The banning of ivermectin prescribing removes a potentially valuable early treatment option for symptomatic COVID-19-infected individuals, in contrast to current health policy of observing such individuals without active treatment until they either get better or worse (and are possibly hospitalized);

(3) The banning of ivermectin prescribing for COVID-19 with the sanctity of the doctor-patient relationship and the freedom of Australians to choose their own health solutions based on their doctor's advice.

We therefore ask the House to ensure the immediate repeal of the TGA statement on Ivermectin, and to provide a firm assurance to the Australian people that overreach of this kind by a Federal Government agency will never again limit access to safe treatments in a non-consultative and unilateral manner.
from 105,201 citizens (Petition No. EN3364)

Maximum amount of family and parent visa grants has been largely decreased from around 7000 to 3600 in recent years. We consider Australia a country with freedom and humanity. Five years ago,143 visa allowed new immigrants to bring parents within 5 years. We love here and decided to move here. After we settled down and called Australia home, things changed, our parent cannot move and we don't have other choice.

We understand pandemic changed the situation and it's a hard time for government, but it shouldn't change the quota of permanent residents' application especially for parents. Even it can, the parents cannot wait.

from 13,271 citizens (Petition No. EN3366)
Veterans

When an application for review of a decision of the Repatriation Commission is made in accordance with Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) s136, VEA s137(1) demands the Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs prepare a report referring to the evidence that is relevant to the review (evidence report), and to cause this evidence report to be served on the Applicant…
The Explanatory Memorandum at 29 states, "Each application (for an increase in the rate of pension) is decided separately and is subject to a separate review process"…

As a matter of course the Secretary routinely places evidence from different applications for review into a single Evidence Report, this practice is contrary to the Memorandum, and not only can it cause confusion, but also raises questions in regard "relevance", as evidence relevant to one matter will, in some instances not be relevant to a different matter…

It needs noting there are a number of ways an Applicant might deal with a review, including withdrawing (VEA s155(2)). And in this instance irrelevant information will definitely be before the VRB. It may also be that some applications for review can be dealt with more quickly than others, even on the papers, in this instance the practice of bundling evidence will result in unnecessary delay.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes as to ensure the Secretary revert to strictly conforming to Parliamentary intent as outlined in the Memorandum, and cease the practice of compiling evidence reports with evidence from multiple matters.

"The voluntary consent of the human subject is absolutely essential. from six citizens (Petition No. EN3418)
Climate Change: Agriculture Industry

To make a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions of Australian livestock. In Australia, direct livestock emissions account for about 70% of greenhouse gas emissions by the agricultural sector and 11% of total national greenhouse gas emissions which makes it the third largest source of greenhouse gas emissions. Livestock are the dominant source of methane and nitrous oxide, accounting for 56% and 73%, respectively, of Australia's emissions.

Ruminant livestock - cattle, sheep, buffalo, goats, etc- have a fore-stomach (rumen) containing microbes producing methane which is released to the atmosphere by belching. Methane-reducing feed additives, such as tannins and seaweed supplements can inhibit these microbes, and subsequently reduce belching.
For example, feeding one type of seaweed at 3% of the diet has resulted in up to 80% reduction in methane emissions from cattle.

Reduction of methane emissions through feed additives, can reduce methane production and increase productivity of the animal. For a 600 cow dairy herd methane emissions could be reduced by 372 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year and yield more meat.

If just 10% of global ruminant producers has used an additive, it would have the same impact for our climate as removing 100 million cars from the world's roads, and potential increases in livestock productivity could create enough food to feed an additional 23 million people.
We therefore ask the House to develop a national minimum standard to use food additives such as seaweed when farming ruminants.
from 122 citizens (Petition No. EN3420)

The practice of "loot boxes" (or "gacha" in certain games) is essentially gambling in all aspects but the ability to cash out, and are exploitative in all the same ways, as shown by recent research. Other types of micro-transactions also exploit people's desire to save time, or FOMO ("Fear Of Missing Out") for elements like cosmetics. It is such a major problem that countries like Belgium have outright banned loot boxes. As well, the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation has stated that it considers loot boxes to be gambling. While independent MP Andrew Wilkie has proposed age restrictions on games with loot boxes, we believe it doesn't go far enough in curbing the practice.

We therefore ask the House to legislate regulations to restrict the use of these exploitative practices, and in particular ban "loot boxes", and encourage other jurisdictions to introduce regulations as well.

Overweight and obesity is a leading cause of numerous issues in our society today, including Australia's high prevalence of preventable diseases such as type 2 diabetes, heart disease, asthma, dementia and many cancers. Additionally, overweight/obesity is linked with a reduction in employability, increased mental illness and our economically extreme and detrimental public health system costs.

A focus on children's health is critical in order to reduce overweight and obesity among Australians in order to reduce the issues outlined above. One important change that must occur is the prevention of using overweight/obese children in public advertisements UNLESS it is to encourage and promote the PREVENTION of childhood overweight/obesity, whereby the advertisements are not normalising overweight children, but outlining the importance in preventing this.
This legislation will greatly benefit Australia and our evolving society.
We therefore ask the House to introduce a new Bill that will ban the use of unhealthy overweight and obese children in visual marketing and advertisement material.
